PAGE.TITLE: One dimensional Taylor Series
PAGE.DESCRIPTION:
A Taylor series is a series expansion of a function about a point. The Taylor series of a real function $f(x)$ around a point $x=a$ is given by:
$$
f(x) = f(a) + (x-a)f'(a) + \frac{(x-a)^2}{2!} f''(a) + \frac{(x-a)^3}{3!} f'''(a) + \dots + \frac{(x-a)^n}{n!} f^{(n)}(a) + \dots
$$
An alternate way of writing this in summation notion is as follows:
$$
f(x + \delta x ) = f(x) + \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(\delta x)^n}{n!} \frac{d^{(n)}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x}
$$
The McLaurin expansion of a function is the Taylor series expansion around $a=0$

UL.LI: You should be able to write out the Taylor series explicitly and using summation notation.
You should be able to determine the Taylor series expansion for simple functions.
You should be able to explain the difference between the Taylor series and the McLaurin expansion.
